courses.name: Theory of Functions of a Real Variable I
courses.desc: Lebesgue measure and outer measure, measurable functions and the Lebesgue integral, convergence theorems, product measures, and Fubini's theorem. Lp spaces, derivates, derivative, finite variation and absolutely continuous functions. Courses must be taken in sequence. Expected preparation: Mth 412/Mth 512.

courses.name: Theory of Functions of a Real Variable II
courses.desc: Lebesgue measure and outer measure, measurable functions and the Lebesgue integral, convergence theorems, product measures, and Fubini's theorem. Lp spaces, derivates, derivative, finite variation and absolutely continuous functions. Courses must be taken in sequence. Expected preparation: Mth 412/Mth 512.

courses.name: Theory of Functions of a Real Variable III
courses.desc: Lebesgue measure and outer measure, measurable functions and the Lebesgue integral, convergence theorems, product measures, and Fubini's theorem. Lp spaces, derivates, derivative, finite variation and absolutely continuous functions. Courses must be taken in sequence. Expected preparation: Mth 412/Mth 512.

courses.name: Modern Analysis I
courses.desc: Topics from nonlinear analysis, harmonic analysis, analytic functions, ordered vector spaces, analysis on Lie groups, and operator theory. This is the first course in a sequence of three: Mth 614, Mth 615, and Mth 616. Expected preparation: Mth 412/Mth 512.

courses.name: Modern Analysis II
courses.desc: Topics from nonlinear analysis, harmonic analysis, analytic functions, ordered vector spaces, analysis on Lie groups, and operator theory. This is the second course in a sequence of three: Mth 614, Mth 615, and Mth 616. Expected preparation: Mth 412/Mth 512.

courses.name: Modern Analysis III
courses.desc: Topics from nonlinear analysis, harmonic analysis, analytic functions, ordered vector spaces, analysis on Lie groups, and operator theory. This is the third course in a sequence of three: Mth 614, Mth 615, and Mth 616. Expected preparation: Mth 412/Mth 512.

courses.name: Functional Analysis I
courses.desc: Hilbert and Banach spaces, the Hahn-Banach, open mapping, and closed graph theorems. Compact, self-adjoint, normal, and Fredholm operators. Locally convex spaces, weak topologies, duality. Banach- and C* -algebras, spectral theory. This is the first course in a sequence of three: Mth 617, Mth 618, and Mth 619 which must be taken in sequence. Expected preparation: Mth 412/Mth 512.

courses.name: Functional Analysis II
courses.desc: Hilbert and Banach spaces, the Hahn-Banach, open mapping, and closed graph theorems. Compact, self-adjoint, normal, and Fredholm operators. Locally convex spaces, weak topologies, duality. Banach- and C* -algebras, spectral theory. This is the second course in a sequence of three: Mth 617, Mth 618, and Mth 619 which must be taken in sequence. Expected preparation: Mth 412/Mth 512.

courses.name: Functional Analysis III
courses.desc: Hilbert and Banach spaces, the Hahn-Banach, open mapping, and closed graph theorems. Compact, self-adjoint, normal, and Fredholm operators. Locally convex spaces, weak topologies, duality. Banach- and C* -algebras, spectral theory. This is the third course in a sequence of three: Mth 617, Mth 618, and Mth 619 which must be taken in sequence. Recommended prerequisite: Mth 412/Mth 512.

courses.name: Advanced Differential Equations I
courses.desc: Advanced theory of dynamial systems and partial differential equations including the basics of partial differential equations, boundary value problems for elliptic equations, the Cauchy problem, and parabolic equations. Topics selected from Hamiltonian systems, waves and shocks, variational methods, control theory. This is the first course in a sequence of three: Mth 621, Mth 622, and Mth 623. Expected preparation: Mth 423/Mth 523 or Mth 472/Mth 572.

courses.name: Advanced Differential Equations II
courses.desc: Advanced theory of dynamial systems and partial differential equations including the basics of partial differential equations, boundary value problems for elliptic equations, the Cauchy problem, and parabolic equations. Topics selected from Hamiltonian systems, waves and shocks, variational methods, control theory. This is the second course in a sequence of three: Mth 621, Mth 622, and Mth 623. Expected preparation: Mth 423/Mth 523 or Mth 472/Mth 572.

courses.name: Advanced Differential Equations III
courses.desc: Advanced theory of dynamial systems and partial differential equations including the basics of partial differential equations, boundary value problems for elliptic equations, the Cauchy problem, and parabolic equations. Topics selected from Hamiltonian systems, waves and shocks, variational methods, control theory. This is the third course in a sequence of three: Mth 621, Mth 622, and Mth 623. Expected preparation: Mth 423/Mth 523 or Mth 472/Mth 572.

courses.name: Advanced Differential Geometry I
courses.desc: Topics selected from differentiable manifolds, differential forms, DeRham cohomology, Lie groups, fibre bundles, the Riemannian metric, affine and Riemannian connections, parallel translations, holonomy, geodesics, curvature, isometric embeddings and hypersurfaces, the Second Fundamental Form, complete Riemannian manifolds and the Hopf-Rinow theorem, spaces of constant curvature, variations of arc length, and the Morse Index theorem. This is the first course in a sequence of three: Mth 624, Mth 625, and Mth 626. Expected preparation: Mth 425/Mth 525.

courses.name: Advanced Differential Geometry II
courses.desc: Topics selected from differentiable manifolds, differential forms, DeRham cohomology, Lie groups, fibre bundles, the Riemannian metric, affine and Riemannian connections, parallel translations, holonomy, geodesics, curvature, isometric embeddings and hypersurfaces, the Second Fundamental Form, complete Riemannian manifolds and the Hopf-Rinow theorem, spaces of constant curvature, variations of arc length, and the Morse Index theorem. This is the second course in a sequence of three: Mth 624, Mth 625, and Mth 626. Expected preparation: Mth 425/Mth 525.

courses.name: Advanced Differential Geometry III
courses.desc: Topics selected from differentiable manifolds, differential forms, DeRham cohomology, Lie groups, fibre bundles, the Riemannian metric, affine and Riemannian connections, parallel translations, holonomy, geodesics, curvature, isometric embeddings and hypersurfaces, the Second Fundamental Form, complete Riemannian manifolds and the Hopf-Rinow theorem, spaces of constant curvature, variations of arc length, and the Morse Index theorem. This is the third course in a sequence of three: Mth 624, Mth 625, and Mth 626. Expected preparation: Mth 425/Mth 525.

courses.name: Algebraic Topology I
courses.desc: Topics from singular and simplicial homology and cohomology theories, fundamental group and covering spaces, CW complexes and elements of homotopy theory, algebraic theory of manifolds, introduction to differential topology and vector bundles, applications. This is the first course in a sequence of three: Mth 634, Mth 635, and Mth 636 which must be taken in sequence. Recommended prerequisites: Mth 435/Mth 535 and Mth 444/Mth 544.

courses.name: Algebraic Topology II
courses.desc: Topics from singular and simplicial homology and cohomology theories, fundamental group and covering spaces, CW complexes and elements of homotopy theory, algebraic theory of manifolds, introduction to differential topology and vector bundles, applications. This is the second course in a sequence of three: Mth 634, Mth 635, and Mth 636 which must be taken in sequence. Expected preparation: Mth 435/Mth 535 and Mth 444/Mth 544.

courses.name: Algebraic Topology III
courses.desc: Topics from singular and simplicial homology and cohomology theories, fundamental group and covering spaces, CW complexes and elements of homotopy theory, algebraic theory of manifolds, introduction to differential topology and vector bundles, applications. This is the third course in a sequence of three: Mth 634, Mth 635, and Mth 636 which must be taken in sequence. Expected preparation: Mth 435/Mth 535 and Mth 444/Mth 544.

courses.name: Geometric Topology I
courses.desc: Topics from geometric and piecewise linear topology, knots and 3-manifolds and gauge theories, geometric structures and geometrization of manifolds, applications to differential topology, vector bundles and to mathematical physics. This is the first course in a sequence of three: Mth 637 Mth 638, and Mth 639. Expected preparation: Mth 436/Mth 536.

courses.name: Geometric Topology II
courses.desc: Topics from geometric and piecewise linear topology, knots and 3-manifolds and gauge theories, geometric structures and geometrization of manifolds, applications to differential topology, vector bundles and to mathematical physics. This is the second course in a sequence of three: Mth 637 Mth 638, and Mth 639. Expected preparation: Mth 436/Mth 536.

courses.name: Geometric Topology III
courses.desc: Topics from geometric and piecewise linear topology, knots and 3-manifolds and gauge theories, geometric structures and geometrization of manifolds, applications to differential topology, vector bundles and to mathematical physics. This is the third course in a sequence of three: Mth 637 Mth 638, and Mth 639. Expected preparation: Mth 436/Mth 536.

courses.name: Modern Algebra I
courses.desc: Topics from groups, semigroups, rings, fields, algebras, and homological algebra. This is the first course in a sequence of three: Mth 641, Mth 642, and Mth 643. Expected preparation: Mth 443/Mth 543 or both Mth 442/Mth 542 and Mth 445/Mth 545.

courses.name: Modern Algebra II
courses.desc: Topics from groups, semigroups, rings, fields, algebras, and homological algebra. This is the second course in a sequence of three: Mth 641, Mth 642, and Mth 643. Expected preparation: Mth 443/Mth 543 or both Mth 442/Mth 542 and Mth 445/Mth 545.

courses.name: Modern Algebra III
courses.desc: Topics from groups, semigroups, rings, fields, algebras, and homological algebra. This is the third  course in a sequence of three: Mth 641, Mth 642, and Mth 643. Expected preparation: Mth 443/Mth 543 or both Mth 442/Mth 542 and Mth 445/Mth 545.

courses.name: Advanced Numerical Analysis I
courses.desc: An advanced study of numerical methods with emphasis on theory, economy of computation, and the solution of pathological problems. Topics will typically be chosen from: evaluation of functions, roots of equations, quadrature, ordinary and partial differential equations, integral equations, eigenvalues, construction of approximating functions, orthonomalizing codes, and treatment of singularities. This is the first course in a sequence of three: Mth 651, Mth 652, and Mth 653 which must be taken in sequence. Expected preparation: Mth 453/Mth 553.

courses.name: Advanced Numerical Analysis II
courses.desc: An advanced study of numerical methods with emphasis on theory, economy of computation, and the solution of pathological problems. Topics will typically be chosen from: evaluation of functions, roots of equations, quadrature, ordinary and partial differential equations, integral equations, eigenvalues, construction of approximating functions, orthonomalizing codes, and treatment of singularities. This is the second course in a sequence of three: Mth 651, Mth 652, and Mth 653 which must be taken in sequence. Expected preparation: Mth 453/Mth 553.

courses.name: Advanced Numerical Analysis III
courses.desc: An advanced study of numerical methods with emphasis on theory, economy of computation, and the solution of pathological problems. Topics will typically be chosen from: evaluation of functions, roots of equations, quadrature, ordinary and partial differential equations, integral equations, eigenvalues, construction of approximating functions, orthonomalizing codes, and treatment of singularities. This is the third course in a sequence of three: Mth 651, Mth 652, and Mth 653 which must be taken in sequence. Expected preparation: Mth 453/Mth 553.

courses.name: Algebraic Graph Theory I
courses.desc: Topics selected from algebraic and spectral graph theory, including automorphism groups, transitivity, primitivity, homomorphisms, generalized polygons, designs, projective planes, cores, fractional colorings and cliques, spectral decomposition, eigenvalue interlacing, strongly-regular and distance-regular graphs, line graphs, root systems, graph laplacians, graph polynomials, and graph-theoretic link invariants. This is the first course in a sequence of three: Mth 661, Mth 662, and Mth 663 which must be taken in sequence.

courses.name: Algebraic Graph Theory II
courses.desc: Topics selected from algebraic and spectral graph theory, including automorphism groups, transitivity, primitivity, homomorphisms, generalized polygons, designs, projective planes, cores, fractional colorings and cliques, spectral decomposition, eigenvalue interlacing, strongly-regular and distance-regular graphs, line graphs, root systems, graph laplacians, graph polynomials, and graph-theoretic link invariants. This is the second course in a sequence of three: Mth 661, Mth 662, and Mth 663 which must be taken in sequence.

courses.name: Algebraic Graph Theory III
courses.desc: Topics selected from algebraic and spectral graph theory, including automorphism groups, transitivity, primitivity, homomorphisms, generalized polygons, designs, projective planes, cores, fractional colorings and cliques, spectral decomposition, eigenvalue interlacing, strongly-regular and distance-regular graphs, line graphs, root systems, graph laplacians, graph polynomials, and graph-theoretic link invariants. This is the third course in a sequence of three: Mth 661, Mth 662, and Mth 663 which must be taken in sequence.

courses.name: Stochastic Processes and Probability Theory I
courses.desc: Sets, spaces, and measures. Probability distributions. Random variables. Dependence. Limit theorems. Birth and death processes and Markov processes. Mathematical statistics, hypothesis testing, and sequential analysis. Selected applications. This is the first course in a sequence of three: Mth 667, Mth 668, Mth 669 which must be taken in sequence. Expected preparation: Mth 411/Mth 511, Stat 463/Stat 563.

courses.name: Stochastic Processes and Probability Theory II
courses.desc: Sets, spaces, and measures. Probability distributions. Random variables. Dependence. Limit theorems. Birth and death processes and Markov processes. Mathematical statistics, hypothesis testing, and sequential analysis. Selected applications. This is the second course in a sequence of three: Mth 667, Mth 668, Mth 669 which must be taken in sequence. Expected preparation: Mth 411/Mth 511, Stat 463/Stat 563.

courses.name: Stochastic Processes and Probability Theory III
courses.desc: Sets, spaces, and measures. Probability distributions. Random variables. Dependence. Limit theorems. Birth and death processes and Markov processes. Mathematical statistics, hypothesis testing, and sequential analysis. Selected applications. This is the third course in a sequence of three: Mth 667, Mth 668, Mth 669 which must be taken in sequence. Expected preparation: Mth 411/Mth 511, Stat 463/Stat 563.

courses.name: Introduction to Research in Mathematics Education
courses.desc: Topics in the history of mathematics education including an examination of the current research trends in mathematics education.

courses.name: Curriculum in Mathematics Education
courses.desc: An analysis of curriculum development and assessment efforts in mathematics education both past and present.

courses.name: Research Methodology and Design
courses.desc: An examination of quantitative and qualitative research methodologies and their applications to the design of research in mathematics education.

courses.name: Research on the Learning of Mathematics
courses.desc: An analysis of the mathematics education research on the learning of mathematics, including topics from K-16 mathematics.

courses.name: Research on the Teaching of Mathematics
courses.desc: An analysis of the research on the teaching of mathematics, including issues from levels K-16.

courses.name: Topics in Research in Mathematics Education
courses.desc: A special topics seminar devoted to exploring particular issues in more depth.
